questions.text: A 55 years old woman underwent a modified radical mastectomy 3 months back for breast cancer, which was located in the upper outer quadrant of left breast. Now, she developed painless swelling in the left upper limb, whose image is given below. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lymphoedema in western countries is POST MASTECTOMY RADIOTHERAPY

  • The incidence of lymphedema : With SLNB, incidence has reduced.
  • Increased risk of lymphedema :
    • If axillary clearance + radiotherapy are given to axilla.
    • Occurence of arm infections
  • management of lymphedema :
    • Arm stocking, exercises.
  • Long standing lymphedema (6- 10 years) can develop secondary malignancy Known as Stewart Treves syndrome. Development Angiosarcoma in a Long Standing lymphedematous limb.
    • Bluish/ reddish nodules
    • management : Forequarter amputation:
    • Poor prognosis

questions.text: After a total thyroidectomy under GA, the anesthetist tried to extubate the patient but he was unable to extubate. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
• In b\l recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, both the abductor's of vocal cords(posterior cricoarytenoid-safety muscle of larynx) is paralysed
  • So the vocal cords come into cadaveric position which is very dangerous leading to stridor
  • If u\l recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, there will be only hoarseness of voice
  • If external laryngeal nerve injury, there will be husky voice
  • If internal laryngeal nerve injury -leads to aspiration, as sensory innervation of larynx is lost

choices.text: Propranolol is the initial drug to be started
Surgery is the treatment of choice
VMA and catecholamines are the diagnostic tests

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about management of pheochromocytoma patient except:
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma are tumour arising from:

  • Adrenal medulla (in 90% cases)
  • Extra adrenal (in 10% cases)

Pheochromocytoma is characterised by:

  1. Hypertension
  2. Diaphoresis
  3. Headache -paroxysmal

Can be remembered by pnemonic(PPP-Pressure, Perspiration, Pain)

  • Screening investigation: raised plasma metanephrines
  • Investigation of choice: 24hr urinary metanephrins >> urinary VMA

After diagnosis is confirmed

  • investigation of choice is MRI abdomen, contrast CT not done as it can precipitate the hypertensive crisis
  • New update: DOTATATE scan to see mets

Pre-op preparation in patients posted for surgery

  • Alpha blocker(prazosin) given until the patient develops postural hypotension
  • Beta blocker is started later after alpha blockade is achieved (pt develops postural hypotension), if started earlier there will be unapproved alpha action precipitating hypertensive crisis

Definitive surgery: LAP ADRENALECTOMY

questions.text: On removal of the submandibular gland and its duct, which of the following nerves is most commonly injured?
questions.solution:
Nerves injured in submandibular gland surgery:

2 superficial nerves :

  • Marginal mandibular nerve branch of facial nerve
  • Cervical branch of facial nerve

2 deep nerves:

  • Lingual nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve

Submandibular gland duct is in very close relation with LINGUAL NERVE >> HYPOGLOSSAL NERVE, so lingual injury is more common during removal of submandibular gland and duct

questions.text: A 50 years old male presented to the hospital with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. On evaluation, air was present in the CBD. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Gallstone ileus is an infrequent complication (0.4%) of cholelithiasis, occurring as a result of impaction of one or more gallstones within the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It is seen more frequently in the elderly and in women. Frequently an episode of acute cholecystitis leads to erosion of infamed tissues, resulting in a cholecystointestinal fstula.
  • A majority of small gallstones pass through the intestines spontaneously. However, gallstones of size 2-5 cm get impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve

    owing to the relatively narrow lumen and less active peristalsis here. Less common locations include the stomach and the duodenum (Bouveret's syndrome). Impacted stones may lead to necrosis and perforation followed by peritonitis.

RIGLER'S TRIAD of gallstone ileus

  • Cholecystoduodenal fistula
  • Tumbling intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumobilia( air in biliary tract)

CT is considered superior to plain radiographs or USG, with a sensitivity of up to 93%. It additionally shows an abnormal gallbladder with air, an air-fuid level or fuid accumulation with an irregular wall.

KEYTAKEAWAYS:

Gallstone ileus: stone obstructing the ileum

Bouveret syndrome: stone obstructing pylorus or duodenum

questions.text: A 45 years old female patient presented to hospital with obstructive jaundice and CBD stone. Patient has a history of cholecystectomy, done 2 years back'. What is the type of stone seen in the CBD?
questions.solution:
• CBD stones, or choledocholithiasis, are generally silent, and are seen in up to 10% of patients undergoing biliary imaging.
  • Primary common duct stones arise de novo in the bile duct, and secondary common duct stones pass from the gallbladder into the bile duct.
  • Primary common duct stones are generally brown pigment stones, a combination of precipitated bile pigments and cholesterol. Brown pigment stones are associated with bacterial infections where free bilirubin is formed by hydrolyzing enzymes released by bacteria and then precipitates. Brown pigment stones are more common in Asian populations. Secondary stones are more common in the United States.
  • Retained stones are secondary stones found in bile duct within 2 years of cholecystectomy and occur in 1% to 2% of patients
  • Recurrent stones: formed after 2 yrs of cholecystectomy. They are usually brown pigment stones, they are also called as primary bile duct stone.
  • When symptomatic, common duct stones clinical manifestations range from biliary colic to obstructive jaundice, including darkening of the urine, scleral icterus, and lightening of the stools.
  • Jaundice with choledocholithiasis is more likely to be painful because the onset of obstruction is acute, causing rapid distention of the bile duct and activation of pain fibers.
  • Cholangitis presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice, known as Charcot triad, and may progress to septic shock with mental status changes, and hypotension, known as Reynolds pentad, which is an ominous sign, and mortality approaches 100% without prompt treatment.

KEYTAKEAWAYS:

Missed stone\ retained stone: formed within 2yrs of cholecystectomy

Recurrent stones: formed after 2 yrs of cholecystectomy. They are usually brown pigment stones, they are also called as primary bile duct stone.

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient presented to emergency with acute abdominal pain and distention. A fluid filled lesion is present in the epigastric region. Which of the following parameters will be raised?
questions.solution:
A 40 years old male patient presented to emergency with acute abdominal pain and distention and A fluid filled lesion is present in the epigastric region suggesting PSEUDOCYST OF PANCREAS. And serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase in pancreatitis.

  • A pseudocyst is a collection of amylase-rich fuid enclosed in a well-defned wall of fibrous or granulation tissue. Pseudocysts typically arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis, lie outside the pancreas and represent an APFC (acute peri pancreatic fluid collection) that has not resolved and matured.
  • Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. The term 'pseudocyst' is often used more loosely to include sterile walled of necrosis that has failed to resolve or a collection that has developed in the context of chronic pancreatitis or after pancreatic trauma. More than half have a communication with the main pancreatic duct. Pseudocysts are often single but are occasionally multiple.
  • The fuid should be sent for measurement of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels, amylase levels and cytology. Fluid from a pseudocyst typically has a low CEA level, and levels above 400 ng/mL are suggestive of a mucinous neoplasm. Pseudocyst fuid usually has a high amylase level, but that is not diagnostic as a tumour that communicates with the duct system may yield similar fndings.
  • Pseudocysts usually resolve spontaneously, but complications can develop. . Pseudocysts that are thick walled or large (>6 cm in diameter), have lasted for a long time (over 12 weeks) or have arisen in the context of chronic pancreatitis are less likely to resolve spontaneously.
  • Therapeutic intervention is advised only if the pseudocyst causes symptoms, complications develop or distinction has to be made between a pseudocyst and a tumour.

IOC: CECT abdomen

Management: internal drainage by cystogsatrostomy

questions.text: A 9 years old male child was brought to emergency by the mother with difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. He was noted to play unsupervised. An X-ray was taken. Identify the location of foreign body?
questions.solution:
Coin is in the esophagus because in the front view the coin is en face and tangentially in the lateral view.

If the coin is in trachea, tangential in front view and en face in lateral view.

So we remove coins from the esophagus with the help of endoscopy.

choices.text: Right lobe hepatectomy with radical gastrectomy

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient presented to the hospital with gastric outlet obstruction. On evaluation, there was antral gastric carcinoma extending to the head of pancreas with multiple metastasis to the right lobe of liver. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Above history of gastric antral carcinoma extending to the head of pancreas with multiple mets to right lobe of liver is a high grade(stage 4) cancer making it surgically inoperable so palliative management is done

Palliative surgery

  • In patients with significant symptoms of either obstruction or bleeding, palliative resection is appropriate.
  • A palliative gastrectomy need not be radical as it is sufficient to remove the tumor and reconstruct the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Sometimesit is impossible to resect an obstructing tumor in the distal stomach and other palliative procedures need to be considered.
  • A high gastroenterostomy is a poor operation that very frequently does not allow the stomach to empty adequately and may produce the additional problem of bile reflux.
  • A Roux loop with a wide anastomosis between the stomach and jejunum may be a better option, although even this may not allow the stomach to empty well.
  • For inoperable tumors situated in the cardia, palliative intubation or stenting can be used.

questions.text: An 18 months old male child was brought to the hospital with multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting and poor feeding. The child was passing dry pellets like stools. Which of the following findings will be seen?
questions.solution:
INFANTILE HYPERTROPHIC PYLORIC STENOSIS

  • Pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting starting between 2 and 6 weeks of age.
  • The diagnosis is made on a test feed or on abdominal ultrasound showing a thickened and lengthened pylorus.In a test feed, gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric 'tumor' is palpable as an 'olive' in the right upper quadrant.
  • Feeds are discontinued, and the stomach is emptied with an 8-10Fr nasogastric tube.
  • Loss of gastric acid causes a hypochloremic, hypokalaemic alkalosis and renal compensation results in paradoxical aciduria.
  • correction may take 24-48 hours; 0.9% saline with 0.15% KCl in 5% glucose given at 6-7.5 mL/kg/h provides maintenance and corrects defects in most babies.
  • Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is performed laparoscopically or through a supraumbilical or right upper quadrant incision.
  • Postoperatively, intravenous fluids are continued until feeds are re-established within 24 hours. Early postoperative vomiting usually swiftly resolves, with GOR being more likely than an incomplete myotomy if it persists.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with pain in abdomen and fever for 3 days and dehydrated face. Abdominal X-ray images are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pain in abdomen and fever for 3 days and dehydrated face. Abdominal X-ray images suggest subdiaphragmatic collection. All suggest infective etiology mostly liver abscess.
  • bacteria remain the most common cause. although infection is usually polymicrobial Klebsiella, Escherichia coli and the Streptococcus milleri group are the usual organisms identifed.
  • Biliary tract pathology is the most common source (35%), followed by portal spread from the gastrointestinal tract, including diverticulitis and appendicitis (20%). Other unusual aetiologies include contiguous spread from subphrenic or intra-abdominal collections, bacteraemia secondary to trauma or infected cysts and necrotic tumours following chemotherapy.

IOC- CECT abdomen

X-ray features of liver abscess:

  • Right sided elevated diaphragm
  • Treatment of liver abscesses initially requires identification of the source, if possible, aspiration of the lesion for microbiology and culture (repeated aspirations may be required) and treatment with appropriate antibiotics.
  • Simple cysts containing debris, hydatid cysts, necrotic tumors and non-infected haematomas (after unrecognized or occasional trivial trauma) can all be mistaken for abscesses. Antibiotic treatment using a combination of two or more antibiotics is recommended.
  • Metronidazole and clindamycin provide wide anaerobic coverage and excellent penetration into the abscess cavity.
  • Third-generation cephalosporins and aminoglycosides are very effective against most Gram-negative organisms.

questions.text: A 55 years old patient underwent hysterectomy 2 years back, now presented with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. On examination, the abdomen was tender with exaggerated bowel sounds. On investigations, multiple air fluid levels were seen in the abdomen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presented with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. On examination, the abdomen was tender with exaggerated bowel sounds. On investigations, multiple air fluid levels were seen in the abdomen suggesting intestinal obstruction. And having a history of hysterectomy 2 years back so mostly due to adhesion.

Common causes of small bowel obstruction:

  1. Adhesions (40%)
  2. Malignancy (15%)
  3. Inflammatory bowel disease (15%)
  4. Hernia's (12%)
  5. Others

Adhesions

adhesions and bands are the most common cause of intestinal obstruction.The lifetime risk of requiring an admission to hospital for adhesional small bowel obstruction subsequent to abdominal surgery is approximately 4% and the risk of requiring a laparotomy around 2%. Adhesions start to form within hours of abdominal surgery. In the early postoperative period, the onset of such a mechanical obstruction may be difficult to differentiate from paralytic ileus.

X-RAY findings of SBO: >5 AIR FLUID LEVELS - in stepladder pattern characteristic of adhesive small bowel obstruction

Management:

  • Patient is kept nill per oral (NPO) for 24-48 hrs)
  • IV fluids
  • Ryle's tube aspiration (RTA)

If not relieved gold standard treatment: LAPAROSCOPIC ADHESIOLYSIS

choices.text: Indirect hernia and Bassini repair

questions.text: A 54 years old male presented with right groin swelling, located above inguinal ligament, medial to inferior epigastric artery. Cough impulse was present. What is the type of hernia and its management?
questions.solution:
Hernia is medial to inferior epigastric arteries through hesslebach's triangle suggesting direct hernia and nowadays Lichtenstein repair is a management option for open hernia surgery.

Open flat mesh repair

Synthetic mesh has been used since the 1950s to reinforce hernia repair, and in the 1980s Lichtenstein described a tension-free, simple, fat, polypropylene mesh repair for inguinal hernia.

The initial part of the operation is identical to Bassini's. Once the hernia sac has been removed and any medial defect closed, a piece of mesh measuring 8 * 15 cm is placed over the posterior wall, behind the spermatic cord, and is slit to wrap around the spermatic cord at the deep inguinal ring.

Loose sutures hold the mesh to the inguinal ligament and conjoint tendon. Two major advantages are claimed: lower hernia recurrence rates and accelerated postoperative recovery.

questions.text: A 25 years old patient presented with abdominal pain and distension. Abdominal X-ray revealed the below image. Identify the prominent structure seen in the image:
questions.solution: The jejunum is characterized by its valvulae conniventes (valves of kerkring) which completely pass across the width of the bowel and are regularly spaced, giving a 'concertina' or ladder effect.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with paralysis operated for rectal prolapse as shown in the image. Which of the following procedures is done?
questions.solution:
In Rectal prolapse option a is not the treatment option.

Image suggest perineal procedure so option b is also ruled out which is well's procedure (abdominal procedure)

Thiersch's operation.

  • Thiersch wiring
  • Used In high risk patient with rectal prolapse
  • Considered procedure a palliative
  • Can be used in children for temporary relief until the base pathology is managed.

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, weight loss & sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis of the urinary tract : features like weight loss with sterile Pyuria is suggestive of TB of urinary tract

Features of chronic TB of kidney

  • Putty kidney
  • Kehr's kink
  • Corkscrew golf hole ureter
  • Thimble bladder
  • Putty kidney: extensive dystrophic calcification involving all or most of the kidney, seen as calcified non-functioning renal tissue
  • The disease gradually involves the bladder musculature, which is replaced by fibrous tissue, causing a decrease in the size and capacity of the bladder('thimble' bladder).
  • Urinary bladder involvement is responsible for urinary frequency, which is the most common symptom of GUTB.
  • For microbiological confirmation, at least three consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. The gold standard for microbiological diagnosis is urine culture. .
  • IVU can pick up the earliest signs of disease activity, such as calyceal distortion.
  • Treatment involves short-course antituberculous therapy (ATT). Rifampicin, isoniazid and pyrazinamide are used sometimes with ethambutol as first-line drugs.

questions.text: A patient underwent radical cysto-prostatectomy and the specimen is given below. Identify the etiology:
questions.solution: Specimens suggest radical cysto prostatectomy that is the treatment option for Ca bladder.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment option for a 85 years old patient, known case of prostate cancer with Gleason score 6, having 2 * 3 cm nodule in prostate and level of PSA is 8 ng/ml?
questions.solution:
• Age is more than 70 so surgical options are ruled out.
  • Subcapsular orchidectomy can be done in old patients with prostatic ca
  • And all findings are not matched with suspicion of Ca prostate so regular follow up is the ideal.
  • Low-risk disease: For men in their seventies, c vative treatment would usually be the correct approach. Radical surgical treatment might be considered in younger (<70 years) men with this form of the disease and/or with a family history, although, even in this group, some men will elect to pursue a conservative course (active surveillance) when counselled about risks versus benefts (impotence/ incontinence).
  • Intermediate-risk: disease. In younger (<70 years), ftter men, this may be treated by radical prostatectomy or radical radiotherapy. Active monitoring remains an option, particularly for more elderly patients towards the lower end of the risk spectrum. In elderly patients with outfow obstruction, transurethral resection with or without hormone therapy is indicated. The beneft of radical treatment over a conservative approach is likely to be about 25%, given that progression to metastatic disease is of this order of magnitude after 10 years.
  • High-risk disease: These patients are at signifcant risk of disease progression. They need multimodal therapy. Early androgen ablation is favoured if close follow-up is not possible. For the sexually active, a careful conservative approach with the adoption of androgen ablation when symptoms arise is reasonable. Androgen ablation coupled with radiotherapy, perhaps with surgery (radical prostatectomy plus salvage radiotherapy) as part of a multimodal approach, is standard treatment for younger men with T3 disease.
  • Metastatic disease: Once metastases have developed, the outlook is poor. For patients with symptoms, there is no dilemma; androgen ablation will provide symptomatic relief in over two-thirds of patients. For patients with asymptomatic metastases, the timing of treatment is less clear. Systemic chemotherapy with docetaxel should be considered in younger, ftter men.

questions.text: A patient of RTA was brought to the hospital with a left flank bruise associated with hematuria. Patient was hemodynamically stable. Which of the following investigations should be done for hematuria?
questions.solution:
Renal trauma

Ominous sign is : hematuria and flank bruise

Investigation:

Stable patients: IOC- CECT

Unstable patient: IOC: IVP( on table IVP is done)

IVP( intravenous pyelogram is done to all patients undergoing surgery for renal trauma to look for renal perfusion

RTA having left flank bruise associated with hematuria suggest renal trauma.

Conservative management with close surveillance is sufficient in the majority of cases of isolated renal trauma.

Lower grade injuries, sometimes including grade IV, can be managed conservatively with bed rest, antibiotics in case of penetrating injuries and serial hemoglobin estimation.

Re-imaging is usually done after 2-4 days in cases of falling hemoglobin levels, fever or expanding fank mass. Persistent urinary leak can be managed with an internal DJ stent or PCN.

questions.text: A 10 years old boy skids while cycling. The child was stable and abdominal examination was normal. Blood was noticed at the tip of meatus. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Blood at meatus suggests urethral injury so suprapubic cystostomy is ideal.

questions.text: A 56 year old man was working in a benzene factory for a long time. He retired 5 years ago. What would be the possible complication in this patient?

choices.text: Caused by mixed aerobic anaerobic infection
Urinary diversion is required in this patient
Anti-gas gangrene serum should always be considered

questions.text: A 26 years old male was operated for redness over the perineal area. Post op day 5 image is given below. Which of the following statements is correct about this condition?
questions.solution:
Fournier's gangrene (necrotising fasciitis)

This is progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum. It is usually caused by mixed bacterial flora(Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp.,Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). It may be associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation or trauma.

The hallmark is rapid progression from symptoms and signs of cellulitis. There is erythema, swelling, pain and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions but the testis and urethra remain unaffected.It is a surgical emergency.Progression from genitalia to perineum to abdominal wall occurs extremely rapidly. There is an increased risk of bacterial septicaemia. It will lead to death if untreated.

Treatment involves a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and extensive surgical debridement and hyper basic oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 35 years old HIV positive female on ART had a severe migraine headache, for which she was given multiple doses of ergotamine 2 days ago. Now, she presented with claudication of right thigh with some numbness and tingling in the right lower limb and peripheral pulses were feeble. Angiography image is given below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Features suggest chronic arterial stenosis of lower limb in small vessels so option a.b. and c is ruled out it is for large vessels occlusion.

  • Ergotism occurs in patients , particularly under ergotamine therapy for migraine.
  • The principal signs are arterial spasms in the legs, or sometimes also the arms, which can lead to gangrene.
  • Stop the offending drug
  • Intravenous or intra-arterial infusion of sodium nitroprusside or nitroglycerine has proved the only reliably efficacious therapy.
  • If small vessel occlusion seen in DSA, stent placement can be done.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) is ideal for small vessel occlusion.

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presents to the hospital with asymptomatic varicose veins, whose image is given below. Which CEAP classification does the patient fall under?
questions.solution:
Varicose vein but asymptomatic so 2a.

Classification system

The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-aEtiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is widely utilized.

For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease;
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins;
  • C2: varicose veins;
  • C3: oedema;
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema;
  • C4b: LDS or atrophie blanche;
  • C4c Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: healed venous ulcer;
  • C6: active venous ulcer.

Clinical class can be further characterized as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

For aetiological classification:

  • Ec: congenital;
  • Ep: primary;
  • Es: secondary (post-thrombotic);
  • En: no venous cause identified.

For anatomical classification:

  • As: superficial veins;
  • Ap: perforator veins;
  • Ad: deep veins;
  • An: no venous location identified.

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Pr: reflux;
  • Po: obstruction;
  • Pr,o: reflux and obstruction;
  • Pn: no venous pathophysiology identifiable.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient underwent CABG, for which graft was taken from a great saphenous vein. The patient is now complaining of lack of sensation over the medial aspect of leg and foot, associated with heel pain. What is the most likely nerve affected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Great saphenous vein: saphenous nerve

Short saphenous vein: aural nerve

  • The long saphenous vein is the most commonly used venous conduit in CABG as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length and is easy to handle. Historical studies showed a limited long term patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts (50-60% at 10 years).

Complications of standard varicose vein surgery

Complications (minor and major) are reported in up to 20% of patients who undergo traditional varicose vein surgery.

Wound infections, the most common complication, are reduced by prophylactic antibiotics.

Nerve injury is the most common serious complications. The incidence of saphenous nerve neuralgia is up to 7% following GSV stripping to the knee (the incidence is higher with stripping to the ankle).

The incidence of sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury may be as high as 20% and 4%, respectively, following SSV surgery.

The incidence of venous thromboembolic complications is approximately 0.5% following varicose vein surgery; however, patient risk factors must be individually assessed and appropriate prophylaxis administered according to guidelines.

questions.text: An 80 year old female presented with fatigue, pallor. On chest X-ray, anterior mediastinal mass was seen. Patient was diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Thymoma is associated with red cell aplasia

Anterior mediastinal mass most common is thymoma.

Primary tumors of the mediastinum:Thymoma, neurogenic tumors, germ cell tumors and lymphoma are the usual primary tumors of the mediastinum.

In superior mediastinum, lymphoma, thyroid and parathyroid tumor occur.

choices.text: Fluid resuscitation with wide bore needle

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient presented to the emergency with a history of road traffic accident. On examination, the patient had subcutaneous emphysema, absence of air entry on the right side & hypotension. Which of the following will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
History of road traffic accident and On examination, the patient had subcutaneous emphysema, absence of air entry on the right side & hypotension suggest massive pneumothorax or hemothorax.

So in both condition urgent ICD insertion is required

Inserting and managing a chest drain

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease; however, the management of the pleura and of chest drains can be troublesome, even in experienced hands.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle that lies:

  • anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • above the level of the nipple;
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.

  • Meticulous attention to sterility throughout.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; these should only be the serratus anterior is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib.
  • The retaining stitch should be secure but should not obliterate the drain.
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is vital for pneumothorax management but should be omitted if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  • Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph. It is preferable not to apply suction to the drain or clamp and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract, so that the skin incision and the hole in the port is forgotten. Dangers of disconnection and siphoning the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and the drain is small or best averted in other ways apart from clamping.

questions.text: A 25 years old male patient with an alleged history of road traffic accident sustained injury over chest and abdomen. At the time of presentation, systolic BP was 70 mm Hg and pulse rate was 110/minute. Which of the following is the next step?
questions.solution:
Management of blunt injury abdomen:

1st step : assess ABCDE( airway,breathing, circulation,

EFAST to be done to all patient irrespective whether patient is stable or unstable

After this if the patient is

  • Stable: CECT is done
  • Unstable: patient is taken up for laparotomy

Focused abdominal sonography for trauma and extended FAST (FAST and eFAST)

Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is a technique whereby ultrasound (sonography) imaging is used to assess the torso for the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, and is extended into the thoracic cavities and pericardium (eFAST).

There should be no attempt to determine the nature or extent of the specific injury. eFAST is usually a rapid, reproducible, portable and non-invasive bedside test and can be performed at the same time as resuscitation.

eFAST is accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood;however, it is very operator dependent and, especially if the patient is very obese or the bowel is full of gas, it may be unreliable.

questions.text: What is the maneuver shown below?
questions.solution:
Head tilt and chin lift

To relieve upper airway obstruction(to prevent tounge fall back) , the clinician uses two hands to extend the patient's neck. While one hand applies downward pressure to the patient's forehead, the tips of the index and middle fingers of the second hand lift the mandible at the chin, which lifts the tongue from the posterior pharynx. The head-tilt/chin-lift maneuver may be used in any patient in whom cervical spine injury is NOT a concern.

Reference:https://www.uptodate.com/contents/image?imageKey=EM%2F70710.
